votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 20th November, 2025
votes.title: Local Government Reorganisation — Two-Unitary Proposal
votes.description: The defining strategic vote of the Reform administration. Endorsed splitting Lancashire into two unitary councils, replacing the current three-tier structure. CC Azhar Ali's friendly amendment requesting shadow elections not before May 2028 was accepted. All opposition groups plus Conservatives voted against. CC Riggott (Conservative, Chorley) voted against despite his party's national support for unitarisation.
key_facts: Endorsed the two-unitary proposal for Lancashire — the key structural reform
CC Azhar Ali's friendly amendment (shadow elections not before May 2028) was accepted
45-29 split: Reform voted as bloc, all other parties voted against
CC Riggott (Conservative) voted against despite national Conservative support for LGR
This vote directly shapes the future governance of Lancashire

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 20th November, 2025
votes.title: Northern Powerhouse Rail — Motion to Condemn Scrapping
votes.description: Cross-party opposition motion (Progressive Lancashire + Conservative) condemning any attempt to scrap Northern Powerhouse Rail. Originally named Richard Tice MP directly, softened by friendly amendment from CC Lavalette to condemn 'any attempt'. Reform voted as a bloc against, refusing to criticise their national party's position on scrapping NPR — despite the motion also calling for specific Lancashire rail investments (Poulton-Fleetwood, Colne-Skipton, Skelmersdale, Coppull, Hyndburn freight).
key_facts: All opposition groups including Conservatives voted FOR the motion
Reform voted as a bloc AGAINST — refusing to condemn national party position
Motion also called for specific rail investments: Poulton-Fleetwood, Colne-Skipton, Skelmersdale, Coppull, Hyndburn freight
Directly pitted Reform councillors against their own constituents' transport interests
CC Lavalette (Labour) softened wording from naming Tice to "any attempt to scrap"

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor John R Singleton JP
County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 20th November, 2025
votes.title: Civic Pride — National Anthem at Full Council Meetings
votes.description: Reform motion to play the National Anthem at the start of each Full Council meeting, establish a Civic Pride Action Plan with annual Pride of Lancashire Awards, and promote heritage. CC Lavalette's amendment (changing heritage wording to 'celebrating local cultural diversity' and requesting budget allocation) was defeated. 63-0-8 shows even opposition didn't vote against civic pride, though 8 Lib Dem/Labour/Green councillors abstained.
key_facts: National Anthem to be played at start of each Full Council meeting
Annual Pride of Lancashire Awards to be established
63-0-8 — no one voted against, 8 abstentions from Lib Dem/Labour/Green
Labour amendment to add cultural diversity wording and budget was defeated
Highly symbolic Reform-aligned cultural change

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 20th November, 2025
votes.title: Cancellation of Local Elections — Motion Against
votes.description: Cross-party motion against the potential cancellation of local elections linked to LGR. Chief Executive to write to Secretary of State seeking assurance that local elections won't be cancelled, requesting repeal of s.87 Local Government Act 2000. Near-unanimous 63-0-4 — only 4 Labour/Chorley councillors abstained.
key_facts: Near-unanimous cross-party support against potential election cancellation
Chief Executive to write to Secretary of State requesting repeal of s.87 LGA 2000
Letter shared with all Lancashire MPs and Council Leaders
Only 4 Labour/Chorley councillors abstained (Brown, Clifford, Snape, Snow)
Demonstrates cross-party consensus on democratic principles

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 20th November, 2025
votes.title: Morgan & Morecambe Offshore Windfarm Cabling Route
votes.description: Cross-party Conservative/Reform motion (CC Peter Buckley / CC John Singleton) on adverse impacts of the offshore windfarm cabling route. Reform's CC Joshua Roberts broadened scope from Fylde to all Lancashire. Chief Executive to write to Secretary of State and MPs.
key_facts: Cross-party cooperation: Conservative motion, Reform amendment
Scope broadened from Fylde to all Lancashire
Chief Executive to write to Secretary of State and MPs

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 16th October, 2025
votes.title: Fracking/Shale Gas — Reform Amendment (Moratorium + Review vs Permanent Ban)
votes.description: Reform amendment to Labour/Green motion on fracking. Original motion called for LCC to write to government requesting a permanent national ban on fracking. Reform's amendment replaced 'permanent ban' with 'continuation of the moratorium while commissioning a full, independent review of domestic energy sources, including shale gas, renewables, and nuclear'. Conservative CC Riggott voted against the Reform amendment alongside the opposition.
key_facts: Original Labour/Green motion sought permanent national fracking ban
Reform amendment replaced 'permanent ban' with 'evidence-based review of all energy sources'
CC Aidy Riggott (Conservative) voted against the Reform amendment — siding with opposition
Reflects Reform national position on keeping energy options open despite local opposition to fracking

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 16th October, 2025
votes.title: Net Zero Review — Roll Back Non-Statutory Climate Commitments
votes.description: Arguably the most significant policy motion of the Reform administration. Resolved to: review all non-statutory Net Zero decisions, review procurement policies re Net Zero vs value for money, cease voluntary carbon reporting (Annual Emissions Report, GHG inventories), ensure future policies don't include non-statutory Net Zero commitments, rescind Net Zero goals if national legislation changes, and ask Pension Fund Committee to review ESG/Net Zero targets. Lib Dem amendment to add 'Council believes in man-made climate change' was defeated.
key_facts: Effectively rolls back previous administration's climate commitments
Stops voluntary carbon reporting and Annual Emissions Report
Reviews ESG/Net Zero targets in Pension Fund
Removes non-statutory Net Zero from procurement and policy
Lib Dem amendment to affirm man-made climate change was defeated

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 16th October, 2025
votes.title: Educational Attainment of Disadvantaged Pupils — Education Summit
votes.description: Opposition motion (CC Azhar Ali / CC Michael Lavalette) on educational attainment of disadvantaged children. Reform's friendly amendment (CC Joel Tetlow) significantly softened the motion — removed requests to write to Ofsted chair, establish a Poverty Commission, and invite specific individuals. Replaced with a simpler resolution for an education summit chaired by the cabinet member.
key_facts: Reform softened the original Labour/PL motion considerably
Removed references to Ofsted chair, Poverty Commission
Passed an education summit commitment chaired by cabinet member

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 16th October, 2025
votes.title: Reformed Inclusion & Fairness Policy — Replace EDI
votes.description: Cross-party Reform/PL motion (CC Ged Mirfin / CC Azhar Ali) to replace the previous EDI approach with a 'practical fairness' framework. Chief Executive to bring within 12 weeks a Reformed Inclusion & Fairness Policy with structural reforms, unbiased recruitment, staff voice, leadership accountability, measurable goals, and a 'What Good Looks Like' toolkit.
key_facts: Cross-party sponsorship: Reform + Progressive Lancashire
Replaces EDI with 'practical fairness' framework
Includes measurable goals and 'What Good Looks Like' toolkit
Consensus approach: shifts from symbolic to practical inclusion

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 16th October, 2025
votes.title: Members' Allowance Scheme 2025/26 — Freeze at 2024/25 Levels
votes.description: Motion to freeze basic allowance, Special Responsibility Allowances, and Chair/Vice-Chair allowances at 2024/25 levels. Near-unanimous cross-party support demonstrated fiscal restraint. Only CC Duke and CC Howarth (both Lib Dem) abstained.
key_facts: All councillor allowances frozen at 2024/25 levels
Near-unanimous 75-0-2 vote — cross-party support for fiscal restraint
Only 2 Lib Dem abstentions (Duke, Howarth)
Reform demonstrating lead-by-example on public spending

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 17th July, 2025
votes.title: Flags Policy — Amendment to Refer to Scrutiny
votes.description: Amendment by CC Azhar Ali (Progressive Lancashire) to refer the flag policy review to the Community, Cultural, and Corporate Services Scrutiny Committee instead of Cabinet. The substantive motion proposed that only the Union Flag, Flag of England, Lancashire Flag, royal flags, and military flags should be flown on council property.
key_facts: Amendment sought to refer flag policy to scrutiny rather than Cabinet decision
Substantive motion effectively bans pride flags and political/campaign flags from council buildings
52-27 demonstrates strength of Reform majority — only OWL's Adrian Owens voted with Reform
All Conservative, Labour, Lib Dem, Green and Independent (except Owens) voted for the amendment

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 17th July, 2025
votes.title: Disestablish Scrutiny Management Board — Create Budget & Finance Scrutiny Committee
votes.description: Major governance restructuring: disestablished the Scrutiny Management Board and established a new Budget and Finance Scrutiny Committee. Proposed by CC Ged Mirfin following recommendations from the Political Governance Working Group.
key_facts: Scrapped Scrutiny Management Board — replaced with dedicated Budget & Finance Scrutiny Committee
Amended multiple sections of the LCC Constitution (Sections 3, 5, 6, 8, 10B, 10E)
Reform-driven governance restructuring to strengthen budget oversight
CC David Shaw and CC Andy Blake appointed Chair and Deputy Chair of new committee

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 17th July, 2025
votes.title: Violence Against Women and Girls — Member Champion
votes.description: Green motion (CC Samara Barnes / CC Gina Dowding) on VAWG. Reform's CC Maria Jones proposed a friendly amendment broadening the definition to include coercive control, psychological, financial, cultural and post-separation abuse. Passed with cross-party support.
key_facts: Reform's friendly amendment broadened VAWG definition significantly
Council resolved to appoint a member champion for combatting VAWG
Cross-party cooperation: Green motion, Reform amendment, universal support

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 17th July, 2025
votes.title: Free Speech — Culture of Open Debate
votes.description: Reform motion (CC Simon Evans / CC Daniel Matchett) to foster a culture of freedom of speech. CC Azhar Ali (PL) proposed friendly amendment adding Nolan Principles and 'without inciting hatred and division'. Passed with cross-party support. Referenced Baroness Casey's audit on group-based child sexual exploitation.
votes.proposer: CC Simon Evans (Reform UK, Deputy Leader)
key_facts: Reform-PL cross-party cooperation: Ali's amendment accepted as friendly
Chief Executive to ensure compliance in all policy reviews
Referenced Baroness Casey's audit on group-based CSE
Nolan Principles added at PL request

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 17th July, 2025
votes.title: Replace First Past the Post with Proportional Representation
votes.description: Green/Lib Dem motion (CC Gina Dowding / CC Almas Razakazi) to advocate replacing FPTP with PR. Lib Dem amendment (CC David Whipp) to add AV for mayoral elections and STV for multi-member wards was defeated. Substantive motion also defeated.
key_facts: Both the amendment and substantive motion were defeated
Reform majority opposed changing the electoral system

votes.meeting: Annual General Meeting, Thursday, 22nd May, 2025
votes.title: Election of Leader of the County Council — Stephen Atkinson
votes.description: CC Stephen Atkinson elected Leader of LCC — no other nominations. Proposed by CC Ged Mirfin, seconded by CC Matthew Salter. First Reform UK council leader in England. Cabinet announced immediately after.
key_facts: First Reform UK council leader in England
No other nominations — elected unopposed

9-member Cabinet announced: Evans (Deputy/Children), Mirfin (Resources), Dalton (ASC), Matchett (Health), Salter (Education), Moore (Growth), Goldsworthy (Highways), Roberts (Rural), Dwyer (Data/Tech)

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 14th March, 2024 1.00 pm
votes.title: Item 5 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Deal - Labour Amendment
votes.description: Labour amendment to the Lancashire Combined County Authority (LCCA) devolution proposal, seeking to give the 12 district councils full voting rights on the new combined authority and to delegate UK Shared Prosperity Fund delivery to districts. The Conservative administration's model proposed upper-tier-only voting membership.
key_facts: District councils would gain full voting rights on the LCCA under this amendment
UK Shared Prosperity Fund delivery would be delegated to districts
3 Liberal Democrat councillors abstained — signalling cross-party unease about sidelining districts
Cllr Michael Green declared a non-pecuniary interest as a South Ribble Borough Council member

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 14th March, 2024 1.00 pm
votes.title: Item 5 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Deal
votes.description: Formal approval to submit the Lancashire Combined County Authority proposal to the Secretary of State, creating a combined authority covering Lancashire CC, Blackpool, and Blackburn with Darwen with devolved powers over transport, housing, skills, and economic development.
key_facts: Creates the LCCA covering Lancashire's 3 upper-tier councils
Devolved powers over transport, housing, skills, economic development
Liberal Democrats joined Conservatives in voting For on the main motion
Labour and Greens voted against despite supporting the consultation phase unanimously in November 2023
District councils have no voting membership on the LCCA

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - Labour Amendment
votes.description: Labour amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing to remove parking income and young persons' travel savings, and add £35 million in capital spending for looked-after children's care, district council housing, and urgent highway repairs.
key_facts: Proposed removing parking pay-and-display income savings (GET007)
Proposed removing young persons' travel savings (GET008)
£5m capital for in-house looked-after children's care provision
£20m assisted housing fund delegated to district councils
£10m for urgent highway repairs
S151 officer warned this would create a 2025/26 deficit of £10.885m
Lost 32-42 on strict party lines

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - Liberal Democrats Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing 6 additional youth workers, 12 parking enforcement officers (one per district), tree planting, and halving the pothole intervention threshold from 40mm to 20mm.
key_facts: 6 additional youth workers + 1 senior (£297k revenue)
12 parking enforcement officers — one per district (£357k revenue)
Tree planting at £2,500 per division (£210k revenue)
Halving pothole intervention threshold from 40mm to 20mm (£4.5m capital, recurrent)
S151 officer warned this would create a 2025/26 deficit of £15.852m
Lost 31-41 — all opposition groups voted together for each other's amendments

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25 - The Green Group Amendment
votes.description: Green Group amendment to the 2024/25 budget proposing a modest £40,000 for on-site renewable energy feasibility studies on council-owned land, including 23 landfill sites. The S151 officer confirmed this could be funded from the Transitional Reserve.
key_facts: Most modest of the 3 amendments — just £40k
On-site renewable energy feasibility studies on council-owned land
23 landfill sites identified as potential sites
S151 officer confirmed it could be funded from the £165m Transitional Reserve
Despite minimal fiscal risk, lost 31-40 on party lines
All opposition groups voted together — revealing the Conservative bloc vote rather than fiscal objection

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Budget Meeting, Full Council, Friday, 23rd February, 2024 10.30 am
votes.title: Budget 2024/25
votes.description: The Conservative administration's main revenue and capital budget for 2024/25, including a 4.99% council tax increase (2.99% core + 2% Adult Social Care precept), setting Band D at £1,653.29. The last full LCC budget before devolution deal progression.
votes.council_tax_change: 4.99% increase (2.99% core + 2% Adult Social Care precept). Band D set at £1,653.29
key_facts: 4.99% total council tax increase — the maximum without a referendum
2.99% core increase was the Localism Act 2011 referendum threshold
Transitional Reserve stood at £165.198m (forecast March 2024)
Collection fund deficit of £2.079m from districts (vs historic £5m surplus)
Squeezed by £7.079m swing on collection fund positions
Home to School Transport demand pressures were a major cost driver
Opposition groups voted against after all three amendments were rejected
Carried 40-29 — comfortable Conservative majority of 11
Cllr Lian Pate declared a non-pecuniary interest (partner was a council employee)

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 14th December, 2023 1.00 pm
votes.title: Notice of Motion 4 - Water Companies
votes.description: Motion on water company accountability prompted by raw sewage discharges on the Fylde Coast during the 2023 tourist season and United Utilities' proposal to raise bills while making £426m in six-month profits. The Conservative amendment was adopted, softening the original Labour motion.
key_facts: Original Labour motion targeted corporate greed and shareholder dividends
Conservative amendment (Cllr Shaun Turner / Cllr Stephen Clarke) reframed as infrastructure challenge
Lib Dem amendment proposed a sewage tax on profits — rejected
Conservative amendment corrected location from 'Blackpool and the Fylde Coast' to 'Fleetwood' (a burst outfall pipe)
28 voted against the watered-down final motion — Labour, Green and Lib Dem opposition

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Extraordinary General Meeting, Full Council, Monday, 27th November, 2023 10.30 am
votes.title: Item 3 - Lancashire Combined County Authority and Devolution Proposal
votes.description: Unanimous approval to launch an 8-week public consultation on creating the Lancashire Combined County Authority, following the government's Autumn Budget Statement announcement. All three upper-tier councils considered the same report. A rare moment of total cross-party agreement.
key_facts: Passed unanimously 58-0-0 — every councillor present voted For
Labour procedural amendment seeking a 30% response threshold for extending consultation was defeated first
Green procedural amendment attempted to change 'agree' to 'note' — withdrawn after legal advice
The unanimous vote contrasts sharply with the 46-28 vote 4 months later on the formal submission
Cllr Azhar Ali OBE proposed the Labour amendment — later suspended by Labour before the 2024 general election

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor John R Singleton JP

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 9th February, 2023 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2023/24 - Labour Group Amendment
votes.description: Labour Group amendment to the 2023/24 revenue budget. The Conservative administration proposed a 4.99% council tax increase (the maximum without referendum). Labour's alternative budget proposed different spending priorities while challenging the Conservatives' record of failed savings delivery (only 48% of targets met).
key_facts: Labour amendment defeated 29-47 with 2 abstentions
Conservative administration imposed 4.99% council tax increase for second year running
Only 48% of savings targets delivered under Conservative administration that year
David Whipp (Lib Dem) was not serving — lost seat in 2021 elections
Vote recorded in printed minutes under Standing Order procedures
votes.data_note: Individual councillor positions recorded in printed minutes under Standing Order procedures; key councillor positions confirmed from party alignment patterns

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 9th February, 2023 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2023/24 - Telecare Services Amendment
votes.description: Cross-party amendment to amend saving proposal A004 relating to Telecare, proposing to maintain free Telecare services for all residents in receipt of Pension Credit. The Conservative administration had proposed charging for Telecare monitoring as part of budget savings. This was an emotive vote about protecting vulnerable elderly residents.
key_facts: Amendment to protect free Telecare for pensioners defeated 30-46
Telecare monitoring provides 24/7 emergency response for vulnerable residents
Conservatives voted to charge pensioners for Telecare as a budget saving
Gained marginally more support (30) than the Labour budget amendment (29)
Vote recorded in printed minutes under Standing Order procedures
votes.data_note: Individual councillor positions recorded in printed minutes under Standing Order procedures; key councillor positions confirmed from party alignment patterns

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 14th February, 2019 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2019/20 - Labour Group Amendment
votes.description: Labour Group amendment to the 2019/20 revenue budget proposing alternative spending priorities. The Conservative administration proposed a 5.99% council tax increase (the maximum without referendum, including 3% adult social care precept). This was the highest council tax rise in LCC history.
key_facts: Labour amendment defeated 32-44 with 4 abstentions
Conservative administration imposed 5.99% council tax increase — the highest in LCC history
This was the first year the government allowed a 3% adult social care precept
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes recorded in printed minutes; key councillor positions confirmed from party alignment patterns

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 14th February, 2019 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2019/20 - Liberal Democrat Group Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat Group amendment to the 2019/20 revenue budget. With only 4 Lib Dem councillors, the amendment had minimal support. Most Labour and Green councillors had already voted on their preferred Labour amendment and did not back this alternative.
key_facts: Lib Dem amendment defeated 4-45 — only the 4 Lib Dem councillors voted for
No cross-party support from Labour, Green or Independents
Demonstrates the Lib Dems' isolation in the 2017-2021 council
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes recorded in printed minutes; key councillor positions confirmed from party alignment patterns. Note: 4-45 total suggests ~35 members abstained or were absent from this specific division.

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 18th October, 2018 1.30 pm
votes.title: Policy Position on the Future Provision of Halal Meat
votes.description: Policy to require that all meat (except poultry) supplied to Lancashire County Council establishments must come from animals stunned before slaughter. One of the most culturally sensitive votes in LCC's recent history, pitting animal welfare against religious freedom.
key_facts: Proposed by the Leader himself — giving it maximum political weight
27 schools across multiple districts were affected
Vote split along cultural and religious lines rather than party lines
Muslim councillors overwhelmingly voted against
Poultry exemption and commitment to consult the Lancashire Council of Mosques were compromise measures
Generated significant national media coverage and community tension in Burnley, Pendle and Blackburn

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP
County Councillor Munsif Dad BEM JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 18th October, 2018 1.30 pm
votes.title: Charter Against Modern Day Slavery
votes.description: Labour motion for LCC to sign the Co-operative Party Charter Against Modern Slavery, committing to procurement safeguards and supply chain transparency. The Conservative amendment accepted the principle but removed the formal charter signing.
key_facts: Conservative amendment (Cllr Geoff Driver / Cllr Albert Atkinson) reframed as 'we already comply'
Dropped the explicit commitment to sign a Co-operative Party (Labour-aligned) charter
New commitments: contractor whistleblowing policies, NCA referral mechanism, annual Cabinet reporting
Classic example of the ruling group co-opting an opposition motion while removing politically inconvenient elements
Some Liberal Democrats voted with Conservatives on the amendment

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP

votes.meeting: Full Council, Thursday, 18th October, 2018 1.30 pm
votes.title: Our Health Our Care A&E Proposals
votes.description: Labour motion opposing NHS proposals to consolidate A&E services in central Lancashire to a single site. The Conservative amendment replaced the strong opposition stance with a call for full NHS consultation, arguing it was premature to take a position.
key_facts: Chorley A&E had been downgraded to an urgent care centre in 2016
Labour motion: 'strongly opposes any proposal for a single site A&E'
Conservative amendment (Cllr Shaun Turner / Cllr Charles Edwards): called for consultation first
Intensely local issue for Chorley and South Ribble councillors
Both motion proposers (Snape, Tomlinson) were South Ribble Labour councillors with direct constituency interest
Cllr Shaun Turner was the go-to Conservative amendment mover — also moved the Water Companies amendment

votes_by_councillor.name: County Councillor Anne Cheetham OBE JP

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 8th February, 2018 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2018/19 - Labour Group Amendment
votes.description: Labour Group amendment proposed by CC Steven Holgate and seconded by CC Azhar Ali. The Conservatives had returned to power in May 2017 and proposed a 5.99% council tax increase — the largest in this entire period. Labour's amendment was defeated 32-47 with 2 abstentions.
key_facts: Labour amendment defeated 32-47-2
CC Azhar Ali seconded — confirmed his leading role in opposition budget strategy
First Conservative budget since returning to power May 2017
Conservatives proposed 5.99% increase — highest in this entire period
votes.data_note: CC Azhar Ali seconded amendment — confirmed. Riggott first elected May 2017.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 8th February, 2018 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2018/19 - Liberal Democrat Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat Group amendment proposed by CC David Whipp and seconded by CC David Howarth. Defeated 33-44-1. Notably got MORE votes (33) than the Labour amendment (32), suggesting some Labour members switched to support the Lib Dem alternative.
key_facts: Lib Dem amendment defeated 33-44-1
Got MORE votes (33) than Labour amendment (32)
CC David Whipp proposed — his most significant solo budget intervention
Suggests some cross-party appeal from Labour/Independent members
votes.data_note: CC David Whipp proposed. Got 1 more vote than Labour amendment.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 8th February, 2018 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2018/19 - Final Budget
votes.description: Final 2018/19 revenue budget. First Conservative budget since returning to power. Carried 42-32-3. The 5.99% council tax increase (3% ASC precept + 2.99% general) was the LARGEST in the entire 2013-2018 period. Tribute paid to Jimmy Armfield OBE DL.
key_facts: Final budget carried 42-32-3
5.99% council tax increase — LARGEST in 2013-2018 period
First Conservative budget since May 2017 return to power
3% ASC precept + 2.99% general increase
votes.data_note: 5.99% increase — highest in period. Riggott voted with Conservative administration.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 9th February, 2017 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2017/18 - Conservative Group Amendment
votes.description: Conservative Group amendment proposed by CC Michael Green and seconded by CC Albert Atkinson. Defeated 31-47. This was the last Labour budget before the May 2017 elections returned Conservatives to power.
key_facts: Conservative amendment defeated 31-47
Last Labour budget before May 2017 Conservative takeover
CC Michael Green moved amendment (not CC Geoff Driver)
Labour chose 3.99% instead of maximum 4.99%
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes inferred from party alignment

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 9th February, 2017 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2017/18 - Final Budget
votes.description: Final 2017/18 revenue budget. Carried 45-30 with 3 abstentions. CC Paul White's road safety amendment (redirecting £0.5M from unused parish bus scheme) was accepted without division. Labour chose a 3.99% increase rather than the maximum 4.99% permitted.
key_facts: Final budget carried 45-30-3
3.99% council tax increase (Band D: £1,174.86 → £1,221.74)
Road safety amendment accepted without division (£0.5M from unused scheme)
Last Labour budget — Conservatives won May 2017 elections
votes.data_note: 3 abstentions likely from Independent group

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 11th February, 2016 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2016/17 - Conservative Group Amendment
votes.description: Conservative Group amendment proposed by CC Geoff Driver and seconded by CC Albert Atkinson. First budget with the Adult Social Care precept (2% ASC + ~2% general = 3.99% total). Defeated 35-43 with 6 abstentions. The Lab-Lib alliance began fracturing — Lib Dems may have abstained.
key_facts: Conservative amendment defeated 35-43-6
First year of Adult Social Care precept (3.99% total increase)
6 abstentions suggest Lab-Lib alliance beginning to fracture
Most contested budget in this period — 7 divisions total
votes.data_note: 6 abstentions likely Lib Dems based on party size. Whipp vote inferred as abstain.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 11th February, 2016 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2016/17 - Liberal Democrat Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat Group amendment proposed by CC Bill Winlow and seconded by CC David Whipp. Only 6 voted for (the Lib Dem group) while 35 abstained (likely Conservatives). The Lab-Lib alliance had clearly collapsed — Labour voted against the Lib Dem amendment.
key_facts: Lib Dem amendment defeated 6-42-35
Dramatic collapse from 2014 when their amendment was CARRIED 46-34
35 abstentions (likely Conservatives)
Lab-Lib alliance completely broken by this point
votes.data_note: CC David Whipp seconded — confirmed for vote. 35 abstentions = Conservative group.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 11th February, 2016 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2016/17 - Independent/Green Amendment
votes.description: Cross-party Independent/Green amendment proposed by CC Paul Hayhurst and seconded by CC Gina Dowding. CARRIED 43-6-34 — the second opposition amendment to pass in this period. Lib Dems voted against, Conservatives abstained.
key_facts: Independent/Green amendment CARRIED 43-6-34
CC Gina Dowding seconded — her most significant budget intervention
Lib Dems (6) voted against; Conservatives (34) abstained
Labour and Independents backed the amendment
votes.data_note: CC Gina Dowding seconded amendment. Whipp voted against as Lib Dem group opposed.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 11th February, 2016 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2016/17 - Green/Whipp Cross-Party Amendment
votes.description: Cross-party amendment proposed by CC Michael Green (Conservative) and seconded by CC David Whipp (Lib Dem). CARRIED UNANIMOUSLY 81-0 — the only vote in this entire period with zero opposition. A rare moment of total cross-party unity.
key_facts: Carried UNANIMOUSLY 81-0 — zero opposition from any party
Only unanimously-carried amendment in 2013-2018 budget history
Cross-party: Conservative proposed, Lib Dem seconded
CC David Whipp seconded — confirmed cross-party cooperation
votes.data_note: Unanimous vote. CC David Whipp seconded. All 81 councillors present voted for.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 11th February, 2016 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2016/17 - Final Budget
votes.description: Final 2016/17 revenue budget incorporating the Independent/Green and Green/Whipp amendments. Carried 42-39 — the CLOSEST budget vote in the entire 2013-2018 period, margin of just 3 votes. The Lab-Lib alliance collapse left Labour exposed.
key_facts: Closest budget vote in 2013-2018: carried by just 3 votes (42-39)
3.99% council tax increase — first year of Adult Social Care precept
Lab-Lib collapse left Labour with razor-thin margin
votes.data_note: Closest budget vote in period. Lib Dems voted against final budget.

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 12th February, 2015 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2015/16 - Conservative Group Amendment
votes.description: Conservative Group amendment proposed by CC Geoff Driver and seconded by CC Albert Atkinson. Defeated on party lines 34-46. CC Bill Winlow (Lib Dem Leader) formally seconded the Labour budget, confirming the Lab-Lib alliance.
key_facts: Conservative amendment defeated 34-46
Lab-Lib alliance confirmed: Lib Dem leader seconded Labour budget
Consistent 34-46 voting pattern across all divisions
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes inferred from party alignment; party totals from recorded division

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 12th February, 2015 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2015/16 - Gooch Amendment
votes.description: Second Conservative amendment proposed by CC Graham Gooch and seconded by CC Michael Green. Defeated on identical party lines 34-46. CC Geoff Driver had to correct a typographical error in his own earlier amendment (£22.466M should have been £30.326M).
key_facts: Second Conservative amendment also defeated 34-46
Identical voting pattern to the first amendment
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes inferred from party alignment; party totals from recorded division

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 12th February, 2015 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2015/16 - Final Budget
votes.description: Final 2015/16 revenue budget proposed by CC David Borrow (Labour Deputy Leader) and formally seconded by CC Bill Winlow (Lib Dem Leader). The Lab-Lib alliance was at its strongest — the Lib Dem leader co-sponsoring the Labour budget. Carried 46-34.
key_facts: Final budget carried 46-34
Lib Dem leader CC Bill Winlow formally seconded the Labour budget
1.99% council tax increase (Band D: £1,107.74 → £1,129.78)
Peak of the Lab-Lib alliance at LCC
votes.data_note: CC Bill Winlow (Lib Dem Leader) formally seconded Labour budget

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 20th February, 2014 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2014/15 - Conservative Group Amendment
votes.description: Conservative Group amendment to the 2014/15 revenue budget proposed by CC Geoff Driver and seconded by CC Albert Atkinson. Defeated on party lines. The Labour administration proposed a 1.99% council tax increase. Budget fell by £21.7M from previous year as austerity began to bite.
key_facts: Conservative amendment defeated 34-48
First Labour budget after winning May 2013 elections
Budget fell by £21.7M from 2013/14
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes inferred from party alignment; party totals from recorded division in minutes

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 20th February, 2014 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2014/15 - Liberal Democrat Amendment
votes.description: Liberal Democrat Group amendment to the 2014/15 revenue budget proposed by CC Bill Winlow and seconded by CC Margaret Brindle. This is the ONLY opposition budget amendment in the 2013-2018 period that was CARRIED. The Lib Dem amendment gained cross-party support from Labour, Green and Independent councillors.
key_facts: Lib Dem amendment CARRIED 46-34 — only opposition amendment to pass in entire 2013-2018 period
Gained full support from Labour, Green and Independent councillors
Demonstrates the Lab-Lib alliance that operated 2014-2015
Vote recorded in minutes but not in ModernGov electronic system
votes.data_note: Individual councillor votes inferred from party alignment; party totals from recorded division

votes.meeting: Full Council (Budget Meeting), Thursday, 20th February, 2014 1.00 pm
votes.title: Revenue Budget 2014/15 - Final Budget (as amended)
votes.description: Final 2014/15 revenue budget as amended by the Liberal Democrat amendment. Carried with opposition from Conservatives only. CC Gina Dowding (Green) ABSTAINED on the final budget — the only non-Conservative to not vote for it.
key_facts: Final budget carried 46-33 with 1 abstention
CC Gina Dowding abstained — only non-Conservative not to support final budget
1.99% council tax increase (Band D: £1,086.13 → £1,107.74)
Budget incorporated the Lib Dem amendment that was carried
votes.data_note: CC Gina Dowding abstention confirmed in meeting minutes

councillors.name: County Councillor John R Singleton JP
County Councillor Mr Joel Michael Tetlow
